summary: The text describes the qualities and achievements of a Roman emperor, likely Vespasian, and his successor, Titus. Vespasian was known for being forgiving, even when insulted by lawyers and philosophers, and was a strict yet admired leader. He triumphed with his son Titus in Jerusalem. Titus, known for his virtuous character and talents, was beloved by people. He excelled in speaking Latin and composing Greek poetry and tragedies. He was noted for exceptional military skills during the Jerusalem siege under his father. As emperor, he showed great civility and generosity, freeing those involved in conspiracies against him and expressing regret if he did not do something worthwhile each day. He constructed an amphitheater in Rome, celebrating its dedication with grand events.
